title: How to stop being picky about food - Quora

response.answer_text: The only way to overcome this is to put yourself on a diet that changes your pickiness. Frankly, I think that all habitual consumption of healthy food is just an extended form of pickiness, and therefore that the rules and intellectual construct of dieting is the best model for what you have to do to change your own eating habits (whether they are healthy or otherwise). But if there was a simple general way for people to change their habits, somebody would’ve written a book about it by now. (And that book would be everywhere, in everybody’s life, because it would work simply and generally and spread rapidly through the grapevine from there, not selectively in only a few people and with a lot of confirmation bias on the part of the readers, like most self-help books.) However, I’m still gonna give you my opinion. Therefore: ——— Five Steps to Transition Yourself to a Healthy Diet: 1.) Start Small If you reflexively gag every time you put lettuce in your mouth, don’t put lettuce in your mouth. Instead, start with a vegetable you can tolerate. If lettuce only makes you cringe a bit, maybe eat one piece of lettuce with every meal every day for a few days. To change yourself, you have to train yourself. Eating a pound of sour-vinaigrette salad with radicchio, kale, and arugula when you’ve grown up on chicken strips and McDonalds is, yes, a healthy choice; but we’re playing the long-term psychological diet game, and as far as that goes, overdoing it on salads makes about as much sense as having someone who’s too skinny to hold a tennis racket at arms’ length try to bench press 300 lbs. (130 kilos for you internationals, 21 stone for you Brits. ;) 2.) Don’t Cheat; Just Lower Your Expectations If you reflexively gag every time you put lettuce in your mouth, you’re probably not the type of person to instantly transition your lunches from white-bread-baloney-mayo-American-“cheese” sandwiches to a sweet-potato-free-range-chicken-avocado bowl. You can go directly to this if you want, but the Oreos will still beckon. To change yourself, you have to be disciplined. To maintain discipline while recognizing your limitations, you have to be deliberate about your cheating. Instead of cutting deserts out of your diet instantly, organize your healthy meals to account for your guilty pleasures. For example: if you know that later on in the day you’re going to have something that is American levels of oversugared and under-nutritious, have something that is relatively low-carb as your prior meal. For example, a serving of hummus-avocado-tofu hotdish with a peanut-butter-and-coconut-oil sauce would be low-carb, and that protein and healthy fat would a much better dietary complement to your sugary “cheating” than even something that was healthy but carb-heavy based. 3.) But Seriously, Don’t Mistake the Cheating for the Diet If you reflexively gag every time you put lettuce in your mouth, you’re probably the type of person who doesn’t want anything to taste like lettuce ever. That want is the problem we’re trying to solve. To change yourself, you have to put yourself in a new context, and then let yourself be shaped by that context. If you started with a less-vegetable-y vegetable like corn or green beans, and you ever start finding that those vegetables are starting to get enjoyable, it means that it’s time for you to move on and pick something new, something that is tolerable, but not yet enjoyable. 4.) Make the Vegetables Boring If you reflexively gag every time you put lettuce in your mouth, it is probably because you’re sensitive to whatever bitterness is contained within lettuce. I’m with you on this one. (This might shock you, but I have only very, very recently recovered from a strong, lifelong, and highly-personal vendetta against lettuce.) Sometimes you can’t change yourself: change the world instead. Bitterness is a weird flavor, and everyone is sensitive to different kinds of it. There are lots of ways to make vegetables less bitter, most of which are just variations on the process called leaching; basically, you boil the vegetables in a pot with water, and then throw out the water. The bitter chemicals (along with some of the nutrients) have probably been boiled away, leaving palatable vegetables. If it’s texture you’re sensitive to, cooking them longer will soften them right up. There’s something divine about a nice home-canned green bean, and the way it just melts in your mouth from the cooking and all the time spent soaking in the just-salty-enough water. Just keep in mind that if health is why you’re doing this, cooking the veggies can alter the nutrient profiles and availability levels, possibly making them less nutritious. 5.) But Seriously, Don’t Make Food Boring Sometimes, you don’t have to change yourself, just distract yourself. Taste buds can be tricked. It turns out, if you cover them with fat, taste buds can’t detect bitterness as well. The fat will also allow good fat-soluble flavor volatiles to leach out of the vegetables, enhancing their overall flavor. The fat masks the flavor of bitter vegetables, so cooking them in fat will make them taste better. (You wonder why people put fatty dressings on salads? This is why.) And of course, fat is not the only way to distract your taste buds from the fact that they’re eating vegetables; sweet sugar, savory miso, sour vinegar or citrus, spicy chipotle seasoning, unctious curryleaf… the reason people put spices and seasonings on their food is ’cause it tastes like crap otherwise, and vegetables are no different. If you make vegetables that taste good, you’re more likely to eat them. For example, anymore I pretty much don’t cook cole crops (broccoli, bok choy, brussels sprouts, etc.) without flavoring them with Chinese brown sauce (that stuff that they have in every Chinese restaurant in the USA, which is a combo of brown sugar, rice vinegar, miso [I use white and a little powdered red], flour for thickening, and garlic). ——— Source that tells how to make a perfectly good and healthy vegetable taste good, even though it’s kind of so bitter that a lot of people don’t like it and instead just call it a weed: Making dandelions palatable

Hello fellow picky eater! I used to be one of the biggest picky eaters in the world as well. I would gag just drinking water, I felt that I had to drink soda and fruit juice as a result. In addition, I also could not stand the vast majority of vegetables, the only one I would eat was boiled cauliflower with cheese sauce. Today, I drink nothing but water, and at times I have eaten 10 cups of salad in a single sitting. Therefore, I will tell you what I did. I personally started with the water issue, I forced myself to drink nothing but water for a month, because I have long known that if you can repeat an activity every day for a month, it becomes much easier afterwards. That month was torture for me, but I forced myself to do it for a month and told myself if I still hated the water after the month I’d go back to the sweet drinks. Well, I got though the month and water was much more tolerable, so I continued drinking nothing but water afterwards. Now, most water is virtually tasteless to me. In the case of vegetables, I did it more gradually. I started by eating foods that I liked already with a small amount of vegetables mixed in. Stuff like omelettes and sub sandwiches. I started with the more tolerable vegetables like onions and bell peppers. After becoming tolerant of those, I started adding more and more variety of vegetables as I went. When I chose to eat out, I would go to subway and slowly increase the amount of veggies that I put on my sub. Over the course of multiple months, I got where I would have EVERY vegetable on my subs when I ate out at subway. When I was in college, I would get a delicious omelette and a plate of spinach next to it. I started by having a tiny bite of spinach when I took a big bite of omelette. Eventually, I adjusted the ratio to increase the amount of spinach and decrease the amount of omelette per bite. I got to the point where I could eat a ratio of like 1:4 omelette to spinach. I would actually go refill my spinach plate before finishing my omelette. At that point, I decided I was ready to try full salads, so I began eating spring mix from the grocery store without taking bites of good food to go with it. I still hated it a lot more than spinach, but I used willpower for a month like I did with water. I finally got to the point where spring mix was not much worse than spinach to me. Even now, I still dislike tomatoes, I’m thinking of making that my next step in the process.

You know understanding people and cultures and who, how, and where food comes from… this changes you alot. Even having a small veggie garden can also help make a difference. We all go through phases and trends as long as we live. Every few years our entire palate changes. Sometimes you have to just FIND A CUISINE that works for you NOW and stay with it. Most go through PIZZA PHASE. Then into Chinese food phase with Fast Food Mexican somewhere in the mix. I went through a salad phase and was eating a fresh salad almost daily for awhile. FIND YOUR CUISINE. It may change within a couple of years or even a couple of weeks. BEGIN TRYING DIFFERENT FOODS ON PURPOSE. Greek maybe. Island. Thai. Soul Food. Southern Cooking. Cajon. German. Scot/Irish. Brit. Get hooked up with some real Italian. Some go through an INDIAN phase but that is way to spicy for me. ALSO you can find 1 simple item you like all along and then WRITE THAT ON A POSTED LIST. I did this for a younger sister who was a very picky eater and always underweight. She liked cucumbers so I began growing those in our backyard. She liked fresh corn and also green beans. Before long we had a running list of things she would eat regularly and it was much more items than we thought and this WILL BE THE CASE FOR YOU ALSO when you begin your own list. Post that list on the side of the fridge and add to it 1 item at a time. START ONLY with the items you like because that is the smaller list to make. I think after awhile you are going to be well farther along the line food wise than you think. Meantime, HAVE FUN WITH THIS AND MAKE IT AN ADVENTURE. My final advice is this: DO NOT GO INTO LIKE VS DISLIKE MODE but elect on a scale of 1 (hate it ) - 5 (love it). 2,3,4 are doable items but not to die for. You can do this = go go go.

Force yourself to try things. The hardest part is the first taste, but once you’ve assimilated it and your brain has made the connection between what the food looks like and what it tastes like, then it automatically sets itself in a position it wasn’t before: one of rationalization and curiosity over one of fear mixed with denial, which perpetuates a mindset of wanting to like the food you told yourself you wouldn’t like. That’s the way I see it, anyways. I’m 21 now, and I eat everything; and I mean everything. Up until the age of 16, I hated cheese if it wasn’t individually wrapped and tasteless, only ate beef it was cooked to absolute char, and would literally gag if I ate dark chocolate. I sort of opened up after that, and since then I’ve been discovering the beautiful world of food. Last summer I was in Malay, and a local taught me how to pull an urchin off the rocks, crack it open, and suck it out like an oyster. Never would I have done that 6 years ago. The greatest tip that I give to my picky friends, and one that may be more up your alley, is watching cooking shows on YouTube, namely those that have a “discovery” viewpoint to lesser known ingredients. First We Feast and Bon Appétit has great series on everything from Poutine, to strawberries, to hamburgers and more! These videos are made to entice you to try the food they’re advertising, and get your mouth watering. Plus, if you’re from a large city center, many of these videos showcase restaurants in your area, if you look it up specifically! That’s the shpeel. Hope this helps! Good luck on your food journey!

You’ve probably been told since you were a toddler to “Eat your vegetables! They’re good for you.” Do you really know WHY they’re good for you? Let me jump into a few reasons why vegetables kick ass. learn How to eat fruits and vegetables 1) Vegetables are nutrient dense. It should be no surprise that Popeye turned to a vegetable when he needed a powerup. Think of vegetables as one of our body’s most efficient fuel sources: they are packed full of vital macro and micronutrients. Just take a look at our article on how to eat healthy on a budget – it should be no surprise that vegetables are an important part of efficiently eating healthy! Simply put: vegetables are the backbone of any solid diet. 2) They fill you up, without “filling you up.” Ever seen what 200 calories worth of broccoli looks like? It’s the size of a grocery bag compared to 200 calories of a doughnut or other treats. If you are feeling hungry but don’t want to overeat, choose a vegetable. Kind of hard to overeat when you’re eating carrots or celery! 3) Veggies keep your body operating at max efficiency! Vegetables are a great way to keep your…um…indoor plumbing…functioning properly. Adding a vegetable or two to each meal is a great way to keep things working right! Seriously: if you’re someone who doesn’t eat many veggies, you will notice a considerable difference after adding veggies to your diet regularly. 4) They can be delicious! Sure, a point of debate…but as a former veggie hater, I am now firmly on Team Vegetable. A plate full of veggies used to make me want to gag, and now I’m thrilled at the idea of a plate covered in a cornucopia (what a great word, right?) of multicolored plants “Ok,” you might be thinking, “I know they’re good for me, but I don’t eat them. Help me!” Okay, okay fine. Here’s how you can get over your vegetable-aversion and get started. Find your gateway vegetable  When I was 22 I proudly proclaimed that I was a “carnivore” and boycotted veggies. Essentially, I ate things like chicken, hamburgers, pizza, pasta, french fries, rice, and not much else. One day, I decided “I’m an adult, I should probably eat like one.” In my mind, all vegetables were disgusting, but the reality was that I hadn’t really tried many different kinds. Instead I tried a few and just assumed they were all bad. So, for starters: stop saying you hate all vegetables. Instead: you simply haven’t found a vegetable that you LIKE yet. I started trying teeny tiny bits of vegetables. If I went out to dinner with friends, I would ask to try some veggies off of their plate. Once I got over the idea, I would order a new vegetable each visit and give it a shot. I did this for two reasons: I figured any vegetable, even if I didn’t like it, and even if I only ate a small bite, was better than nothing.If I found a vegetable I DID like, I could learn to prepare it the same way and eat more at home.On top of that, I simply forced myself to go into any new vegetable with an open mind and positive mindset. It’s amazing what positive or negative expectations can do to convince ourselves. So, instead of thinking “this is gross,” say “this is what I eat and it’s good.” Sounds a bit hokey, but it works. My gateway vegetable: asparagus. I bought some asparagus at the store, put them on a cookie sheet lined with tinfoil, covered them in olive oil, salt, pepper, and stuck them in the oven (at 375 degrees F) for 12 minutes. BAM! Crunchy, delicious, and nutritious. Plus, I felt like a 5 star chef! For my first year as an omnivore, asparagus was the only vegetable I ate. I didn’t branch out too much beyond this, but at least I had found one that I liked. Once I had gotten over the mental barrier that “all vegetables are gross,” it was time for me to branch out. YOUR MISSION: Find your gateway vegetable. (We’ll be giving you some great options later in the article.) Suck it up, take one bite of many different kinds of veggies, and see which ones you actually enjoy. Before each bite, clear your mind, Neo. Stop going into each veggie encounter expecting to hate it! You never know when things change. Many people think in order to eat a “Paleo Diet” you’ll need to eat dozens of veggies everyday, but almost everyone starts just like I did – with only one or two gateway vegetables and slowly branches out from there. Our free download on the Paleo Diet helps show you that it isn’t nearly as complicated as some people can make it out to be.

I know a lot of people like you. Scotland is full of them, for some reason I don’t understand. You could make a resolution to try one new fruit or veg every week - or every day if you’ve got the cash. I’m sure if you do this with an open mind, sooner or later you’ll find a few you like. Make sure if it’s the type you cook that you don’t boil the beast to death. Lightly cooked so it loses its toughness and retains some crunch will give you the best chance to discover a tasty treat. For fungi - various types of mushrooms, well people will tell me I’m bad but I like them best gently fried in butter. Tear them into chunks, put them in a pan with the butter, keep the heat really low and cook for 10–15 minutes. They go great as a side with steak and other chunks of meat. If you’re watching the calories, you can cook them in a little chicken stock instead. In the meantime, well, you realize you’re going to be short on nutrients and fiber without the vegetable kingdom, I’m sure. So you can make up for the fiber with something like psyllium husks or similar, which you can maybe sprinkle on your breakfast cereal or use in a milkshake. Then there are powdered fruit and veg which you can mix into food, which will help with the missing nutrients - or just get yourself a really good one-a-day multivitamin and mineral tablet and take that. But do try and get a taste for the real thing, because for a start you are missing out on a whole world of taste sensation, and there’s really no substitute for the real thing from a health point of view.

How can you stop being a picky eater? Two strategies may help, but in reality, being a picky eater is a choice, in most cases. One strategy that helped my daughter expand her eating selections was to allow her to prepare foods. If my wife or I cooked a grilled cheese sandwich, she would see a dark crust, or some other flaw, and turn up her nose, but if she cooked it, she managed to enjoy it thoroughly no matter how rough it looked. Other stuff came along she didn’t want to try, but as she grew up, she cooked quite a bit, even stuff she didn’t want to eat in the process of helping prepare family meals, and if she invested her time cooking it, she would often actually try it, and more, to her surprise, she would even occasionally like it! Another strategy is to convince yourself or your picky eater to nibble a bit, even if just a tiny bite, and if the taste is offensive, leave that food alone. Trying tiny bits of food is usually easier if only a bit is offered, since the picky eater won’t feel bad about leaving a whole portion on the plate. This worked well for one grand daughter, and failed miserably with the other…until the first found she really liked the stuff, and the second became jealous of her enjoyment. The reality is, though, that some people just cannot overcome picky eating habits, and trying to force the issue is not really a constructive approach. Picky eating can have different causes, sometimes a person has too sensitive a sense of smell, for instance, and sometimes one person’s tastes just don’t agree with others, but in the modern world, there are many different foods to try, and many more ways to prepare, or even, to camouflage them.

Everyone needs proper nutrition to feel well. I don’t think anyone can argue with me on that. It is getting harder and harder to get proper nutrients because of the amount of processed foods that we consume. It seems everything is laden with sugar, flour, and chemicals. This is one reason I started juicing. My journey into juicing was exciting at first. I went to the farmers market and loaded up on organic fruits and vegetables. Then I went to the vitamin store for chia, flax, acai, spriulina, etc. I bought a fancy blender and got started. It was great. I felt better, had more energy, and was in a better mood. You can get very creative when you start juicing. I was even able to put the peelings in from some fruits and vegetables that we do not normally eat because of the fancy blender. After some time though I started losing interest because of the time and expense involved. It took a lot of time and money to keep the items needed in house and it was very expensive. I then went to the vitamin store and started trying meal replacement products. I found this to be a cheaper and easier alternative. I was trying to lose a few pounds and get a good dose of nutrition. I have tried about a dozen of these and I finally found what I think to be the best. I accidentally discovered it while helping someone devise a nutrious weight loss plan. The drink has 100% of the vitamins and minerals needed for all day. I just mix it with a little apple juice. It also has fiber. If you would like more info on this just let me know as I liked it so much I became a distributor. You can reach me at marcia@startahomebiz.com I still have not directly answered your question. If you do not like fruits and vegetables you have basically 2 choices if you want to get proper nutrition. Pick which fruits and vegetables you do not like and find out which nutrients are in them. If you know this you can look for an alternative food that is rich in the nutrient you need. Or you can purchase a drink like the ones described above to supply the missing nutrients. If you let me know specifically what you don’t like I can give you more information. I hope this was helpful. Thank you, Marcia

When my father married my mother, the only vegetables he would eat were green peas and asparagus. He then made a conscious decision - as you have - that being picky was stupid. So he decided to eat anything and everything on his plate, and sure enough he grew to like them. My mother would eat everything except tripe. My father liked tripe. (I’m with my mother on this one). So he forced my mother to have tripe, just the once. She concluded that not only did it smell and taste disgusting, it had a horrible texture as well. Mum did the shopping and cooking though, so from then on Dad could only have tripe when eating out. Fresh fruit and vegetables won’t kill you (not eating them, however, may well contribute to an earlier death). It’s all in your head, so it’s down to you to make the conscious decision to eat them. You can do it. And one day, with luck, you will come across a perfectly-ripe peach.

The DSM-5 (Diagnostic & Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders has a category titled “Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder.” Since I do not know anything about you, I recommend that you look for a psychologist who can help you understand whether your “super picky eater” habits are just habits or if there is something more serious going on. Find a psychologist who has experience in dealing with eating disorders. My son was a super picky eater until about the age of 21. One of his early jobs was working in a high-end grocery store and then in the restaurant attached to the store. The chef demanded that he at least taste all of the foods. If he disliked anything intensely, he had permission to spit it out. But he had to taste. Now he has a wide-ranging palate and will try most foods at least once. So if you cannot accept going to a psychologist, find a job working for a high-end restaurant. If they cannot change your mind about eating a variety of foods, then you could have a true eating disorder and should seek help from a mental health professional.

Use a fork instead of chopsticks. (Yuk-yuk…)  Real advice: Try introducing new foods into your diet gradually. Don't overwhelm yourself with too much change all at once. Maybe try one new food a week, replacing one familiar component of your meal with an alternative (such as a mixture of quinoa and brown rice instead of white rice).Experiment with different methods of preparation. (You may not like mashed potatoes but you might enjoy roasted ones with flavorful seasonings. You may not like oatmeal porridge but you might like baked oatmeal.)Adjust your mentality about trying new foods. Instead of seeing change as an unwelcome disruption and threat to the comfort of your eating routine, think of it as an adventure and an opportunity to experience the variety of foods the world has to offer, and to reap the nutritional benefits of a diverse diet, which eating the same things all the time is depriving you of.Eat with friends and family. Eating with other people who are trying and enjoying different foods may encourage you to do the same more so than eating alone.Best of luck.

First of all, you should consult a doctor and/or nutritionist with good references to oversee your diet adjustments and medical condition. When it comes to changing your eating routines, start very small and try tiny portions of foods recommended to you. Pick one or two of these foods at a time and try to eat a small amount of each for several days in a row. Once you have become used to these new foods, possibly after about two to three weeks, then try introducing one or two more foods. Don’t be discouraged if you have set-backs. Just jump back in and keep trying a little bite at a time. Consult closely with your professional advisors and keep at it. Over time, if you put the effort in, you will find yourself naturally going with the new diet now that you have changed your daily eating routines, and you will likely find that your overall health will gradually improve as well. Changing the way that you eat and think about food will take a lot of repetition, but once you acheive some success, everything will begin to seem a little easier. Good luck, and try to think positively.

I like veggies. Raw, cooked, sautee, pickled, with or witouth dressing, I like most of them and I eat them happily. I don’t like fruit. But I have managed to eat a decent amount of fruit by doing this: First choosing wich fruits I can tolerate, the tricky thing is I just tolerate them for a short amount of time, so now and then I change my choises. Second I buy them fresh, fresh fruit are usually expensive in my country so I feel pain in my pokets if I have to throw it away.And if that happens I know that my taste is already saturated so is time for changing to other fruits. (Still I hate throwing away food so most of the time I make over riped fruit into jams or bread). 3rd I take my fruit for lunch and avoid having anything else or buying anything else (you kiding me? Fruit was the most expensive item in my grosery list, I’m already in debt I’m not buying something else). 4th find a way to like them best. For me I can only think in eating raw some of them (like apples) in juices (oranges) but strawberries bananas and figs I can eat them raw or cooked in jams or bread

How do I stop being picky about food? Thanks for the request to answer. Taste is one of the great mysteries of hu-man consciousness. An old Latin saying states: "De gustibus, non-est disputandum" - meaning "In matters of taste, there can be no disputes". What tastes right or good for one person, need not be so for another and there can be no dispute. All taste is essentially memory. To the extent that memory is a mystery, so is taste. We can train our taste buds. They renew themselves every ten days or so. To acclimatise your taste buds to new flavours and textures hold small amounts of each food in your mouth. Chew it slowly, savouring the flavour. If you do this three times in a row, at one sitting, for any food you seek to develop a taste for, you will see that just by holding the food in your mouth, chewing it slowly you give your tongue a chance to become more familiar with the flavour profile. Being picky means there is a reason. Meditate on why you may not like a particular food. Food is very emotional topic. Perhaps there is some trauma attached to a given food... as often there is. People bury the memory as they grow up, yet, it still affects them. Decide you are not going to be picky. Make a list of foods you are going to educate your taste buds on, and have fun. Eating is not only essential, it is, perhaps, if your diet is clean and healthy, one of the few guilt free pleasures that does not require a ‘licence!’ Applied Meta-physics, The Science of Be-ing and Know-ing

This is a tough one. First off, I do hope you can overcome whatever condition you have. We are incredibly resilient when we take care of ourselves, so hopefully you can recover. Next, you will have to consider something you might not want to. If most of your diet is chocolate and sugar, you likely have some trauma or something packed into that. It isn’t normal and will completely debase both your body and your mind. You might have to seek psychological help in addition to fixing your diet. To change your diet, make it into an adventure. Begin introducing fruits and veggies that are moderate in flavor and texture. It is critically important that you enjoy this experience. DO NOT GET CANNED OR FROZEN fruits and veggies. It will be very difficult to enjoy your experience experimenting if you start with less than quality things. Yes, peas and corn can be good canned, but even they can’t hold a candle to their fresh counterparts. Fruits should be very easy to bring into your diet since they are sugary. Apples will probably be the most healthy for you with their high fiber content and healthy sugar. There are so many different varieties, but some of my favorites are Pacific Rose, Honey Crisp, Fuji, Gala, Cameo, and Jazz apples. For a twist, spread peanut butter on apple slices. For veggies, easy starters would be broccoli, carrots (try to find Nantes carrots), fresh english peas, beets (beets are amazing when prepared right), cauliflower, and winter squashes (delicate, butternut, kabocha). I chose these veggies for their high starch content and moderate flavors. They will be easier for you to get into. It is also likely that you will need to incorporate greens as they are so incredibly healthy. Again, have fun. Experience the soft velvety texture of spinach or the light spice of arugula. Try the butteriness of cabbage or the crisp juiciness of romaine. You can even eat cooked greens like collard greens. And not to get gross or anything, but greens feel even better coming back out. So worth it. Finally, try your best to buy in season, preferably a farmers market. These are usually the freshest and best tasting. You can also talk to the farmers and get to explore new and exciting things as well as learn more about what you will eat. All of it will help you have an enjoyable experience while making the shift. Good luck and I wish the best for you.

It’s an average thing that happens to people at a young age. Dude, you can’t just force yourself to stop being so picky. I really really dislike peas, I tried forcing myself to just swallow them whole/plug my nose while eating them. I couldn’t do it. People grow out of things, some don’t. Let your body be itself. 20 years from now I could love mushrooms or peas, maybe I won’t. I used to hate myself just because I was so picky over the smallest things. People say “Peas don’t have a taste.” Uh hun, I’m sorry what’d you just say? We all have different standpoints. I based myself off of other peoples opinion's everyday when I went to lunch. So many people would make certain comments like “Ew refried beans? Gross!” I tried them in like third grade and I loved them for a long while.

I did it by learning to cook. Take something you already like and make it more elaborate. I pretty much only liked cheese sandwiches and garbage like that as a kid, so I got really good at grilling them. Then I got multiple kinds of cheese. Then I put some pepperoni slices on it (the really cheap crappy kind). I tried pickles and a bit of mayo on it. Eventually, you like cooking, but there are only so many kinds of grilled cheese you can make. You’ll find something similar, but different to make. One day someone will say, “Gross, you eat that?” and you’ll realize that everyone else is pickier than you because all food is fair game to you now.

As a child, I detested eating curd. I don’t remember whether it was the taste or the texture that made me retch every time it touched my tongue. But my parents wouldn’t give up. They kept sneaking it in my food, in minuscule quantities at first, but then substantial. Slowly, I started asking for it myself[1]. Now, after almost two decades, I feel my meals are incomplete without curd. It is surprising to think of such a drastic change. But I am sure you it would have happened with you as well. Give something enough time and you’ll probably get used to it. Psychologists have a term for it – “Mere exposure effect[2]”. It is a phenomenon by which people tend to develop a liking of things that are familiar to them. In scientific experiments, it has been observed that when people are subjected to anything new regularly, they tend to develop an affinity towards it. You can try it as well. Challenge yourself to eat any healthy food item that you loathe, at least once a day, in small portions. Do it for a year, and you’d be able to see the difference. Footnotes[1] I don't like it; I never tried it: Effects of exposure on two-year-old children's food preferences[2] Mere-exposure effect - Wikipedia

Experiment. The first thing you need to remember is that no one and nothing is going to force you to eat a lot of the new foods you try. So just go ahead and try. Set yourself the task of trying a new food each week. Suppose you never tried apples. Buy three different apples. On the first day wash and slice the first. Take a small bite off one slice and chew it. If you don't totally dislike it, try some more. Don't start with preconception, don't expect to hate it or to love it. Just taste it a few times, then decide. The next day try another type of apple, then the next. If you end up liking the apples (or at least one of the apples) you will have added one new food to your repertoire.

If you don’t like individual items, I suggest trying different combinations of them. For example, apples and cheese seperately are their own thing, but together create a whole new experience. So just because you don’t like some vegetables the way you have previously tried them, doesn’t mean there might not be new ways of cooking them, or new ingrediants to try them alongside, that might completely change how you feel about them. So get creative! Also when introducing kids to food, they say the child has to try it as many as 20 times to know if they really like it or not. The child could try banana nine times and hate the texture but on the 10th time they might love it. You could try using this and see if it works at your age too. You could make yourself eat things you don’t like that you know are great for you. After a number of times, you might find you actually love them :) Good luck, I wish you many new great food experiences!

I, myself, is a picky eater. Picky eaters come off as the majority, and then, there’s people who are open to eating anything. People have different palettes, some choose to not eat certain foods for many reasons. I disliked vegetables, as many kids did, growing up and I blamed it on my parents for not forcing me enough to like it. It gets old by the time you hit your 20’s and you realize you need vegetables because it’s healthier than eating baked potatoes and corn, which are just starches (and I don’t reckon corn is a veggie). And because my doctor said so. And I would know so with all the extra weight I put on. Now, if you’re picky, as in you don’t want to eat the people around you diet, then I don’t see the issue. Are the foods you’re missing out on detrimental to your health? You could substitute foods you dislike with others. Like I said before, I have an iffy relationship with vegetable. I started slowly adding vegetable in foods that I liked, or “masked” it to put simply. For example, teriyaki chicken fried rice. I’d put steamed broccoli (when its soggy) with the carrots (minced). I think the earthy taste and texture of vegetables throw me off, but I like eating broccoli whole and carrots as well. It takes practice, just as long as you’re incorporating it to your diet somehow. I disliked avocado (still do) for the most part but started adding seasoning and disguising it with peanut butter. Then, there was also a part of me that forced myself to eat my family’s cooking because they took the time of their busy day to make it for me and that there’s other people out there who’d love to come home to cooked meals but don’t.

Start with tiny bites of a single food that you don't like. And when I say “tiny", I, mean the size of a garden pea. If texture can affect your enjoyment, consider whether some foods might be prepared differently. For instance, many people who don’t like raw tomatoes can handle them in a smooth puree. For now, stick to flavor profiles that you know you enjoy. If you know you like Tex-Mex, don't try to jump into Asian until you're more comfortable with a bigger variety of food. Remember that bitter flavors can be overcome by roasting or sauteing, and sometimes by sauce. (I learned to like a lot of new vegetables by roasting them a few times, and cheese sauce on broccoli is a classic for a reason.) It takes anywhere for five to ten bites for your taste buds to adapt to new flavors, and it doesn't have to hapoen all at once. In fact, it may be easier to learn to like new things if the experience is spread out, which is why I suggest single bites over a period of days.

I learned the hard way you can't be to picky. I grew up on a Dairy 9–10 miles from the closest gas station. We had a failing dairy on top of that. I was the oldest of 7. We bought things in bulk and due to heavy sickness from my mother we had to usually fend for our self. This meant sifting weavel from the flower using eggs from the chickens and scraping the flies and cream off the milk for a very routine pancake dinner. When you eat like that you become either very picky as your accustomed or you will eat anything. No middle ground there. We all became very eat what's given. Oddly because we gave most the greens to the live stock we were steared to eat less veggies. So never really become to accustomed to eat what my food ate.

This might be a situation where you need to seek professional help. Being an extremely picky eater could be categorized as an eating disorder, a form of OCD, depending on the severity of your condition. Unfortunately, I’ve had to deal with this issue with one of my children. You might want to get a medical diagnosis to start. This will help you understand your condition, if you have it. Unfortunately, there isn’t much the medical establishment can do in treating these types of conditions. There are drugs but they have side-effects. May I suggest you try medical hypnotherapy? This is treatment by hypnosis done by an M.D. If you’re in the United States, there is an organization of medical doctors who practice hypnotherapy. Google it. It works. Good luck.

Hello,. You are habituated, if Any one continue to do same thing daily that thing will be habituated. So first we have to mentally prepare ourselves, by training our mind, say to your mind that I can eat food anything .I Am strong.. I can do anything. Anything is possible in life. Nothing is impossible. It may be hard or time takes but definitely you will succeed the goal. Then Slowly try to eat vegetables and fruits in a very small amount first starting. Day by day increase quantity of eating. Keep a goal on eating of vegetables and fruits and good food that keeps your body healthy. Keep trying, definitely you will success. Thank you.

Try more fruits and veg in different ways. It is entirely possible that your grandmothers and mother (or who ever cooked for you as a kid) couldn’t cook vegetables. Try grilling/broiling/roasting vegetables instead of boiling them. Try a bean salad with a tasty vinegary dressing. Make a salad with nice peppery arugula instead of lettuce, or make cole slaw with green and red cabbage and shredded carrot, and nice dressing. Look for vegetable meze recipes, tabooli, baba ghanoush, cucumber salad, etc.

A2A. Erika, the short answer to this question is that I didn't. The longer answer is that, while I've gotten better, the picky eating is still a problem. Here's some ways I've used that have helped me. I prepared and cook my own meals. It gives me a measure of control. I tried it in a different way. My brother hates Brussels sprouts with a passion, but cooked in a casserole, it tastes different. He eats it every time. I can't stand tomatoes or celery, or carrots, but I put all of those in a blender with peppers to make bolognaise sauce. I like spag Bol. Sometimes, you got to experiment. If I'm trying a new sauce, I'll have it on the side. If I don't like it, the meal isn't ruined. And finally, if I don't like something, it is not the end of the world. Big deal. Move on, find something else.

My sister used to be a very picky eater. She never wanted to try new foods. She could littearly live on potatoes and bread because that was only thing she would eat. Then my mum started cooking only foods that she doesn’t want to try. First week she made everything with vegetables, no potato, no bread. She was really hungry so she had to eat it. At first she wasn’t a big fan but after a few days she just got used to vegetables. Now, 5 years later, she loves to try things and vegetables are not a problem anymore. :)

I am an extremely picky eater, and don't really eat much fruits and vegetables. How can I overcome this? Repetition, repetition, repetition. I have the same problem as you. Granted, I enjoy fruits more than you imply you do, but veggies have always been a problem. I decided that I'm an adult and should get over this. I've read some psychology books that showed me the truck I needed, the magic of repetition. Our brains, wonderful as they are, employ a lot of shortcuts. One of these is that, in general, if we do something a lot, we must like it. If we repeat something enough, it must be true. So I started. Every night I would eat a baby carrot, all the while exclaiming to my wife how I love carrots. They're just the best, so bright and orange and crunchy. Never mind I hated them, I would keep eating and talking about how good they were. I still don't love carrots. But I can eat them with no discomfort. I'll stick them in stews or other recipes with none of the hesitation I once had. I've now moved on to broccoli, and while I still dislike them, I can tolerate much more of them. Repeat your exposure in small doses, increase the dose when you can, and soon enough you'll be eating vegetables no problem.

You’re in luck. It’s getting to be colder weather, so stews and soups loaded with veggies ( pureed works, as well) are good choices for you. “The Sneaky Chef” ( Cookbook , seen this on amazon) is a cookbook you really need, check if your local library has it. Fruit cobblers, fruit tarts and other fruit based desserts are good too. About a decade back, I had the privilege of meeting the author of “Wow, this is Sugar Free?”, fruit desserts with no cane sugar added are her specialty. And as other answers pointed out, vegetable juices and fruit smoothies are an option as well.

Well to help myself eat healthier (overall, not just fruits and veggies) right after I go to the store I weigh my food and divide it up into the portions I want. I would do this with fruits and veggies. The idea of having to eat one serving is less intimidating than looking at a whole bag of food. It’s a lot of work getting back from the store but makes it MUCH easier later on. Also, like others have mentioned, try a bunch of different fruits and veggies, and try them cooked or raw or whatever. There’s lots of recipes online. In addition, my sister and I got my dad a “fruit of the month” subscription for a year, and the place we got it from delivered fruit that we had never had before. And they weren’t huge portions either.

Consider that in our modern day much of the food supply had been adulterated with chemical flavorings and additives. Unfortunately these have altered the chemistry of many people's brains. The effect is that we are pushed out of balance related to our inborn, natural ability to discern what foods to eat. We reach a point where a person finds foods that are highly nutritious unappealing. The most reasonable strategy is to remove the toxins from your diet, detoxify your brain but starving it of these highly toxic, addictive chemical additives and rebalance and reawaken you innate sense of eating what is healthy for you.

Well, I would suggest you make a concerted effort to try some possibilities; you could do it at home where no one would witness your reaction; or you could try with friends that are supportive, and would help you choose things that might work for you. Some people would actually be supportive, and happy to open you to a new world of culinary delights. You might start by familiarizing yourself with seasoning families that you do like, and which ones turn your taste buds off, so that would help when reading menus, and helping you choose something new. In a restaurant, if it is served as an appetizer, that might be a way to go, also.

Think about why you like several different foods that you do like. Because they are sweet, crispy, juicy, salty, fatty, sour, crunchy, mushy, etc. etc.? Then try a couple of new foods that have some of these qualities. For example, if you like potato chips, try plantain chips. If you like soft scrambled eggs, try broken-up tofu. If you like apples, try hard pears.

Try something new once a week. Start with not spicy things like rice, potato, pasta. Choose a new veggie or fruit and a new way to prepare it. You don’t need to make a meal of it just a sample. Try with different spices or methods of cooking. Something like a yam, it can be with just butter, butter and salt, mashed with marshmallows, butter and different spices like ginger. Eat one bite of each method and you might find one you don’t hate and you ate a full serving of just samples. Fruit is mostly sweet so eating 3 grapes, or strawberries shouldn’t be awful, try blueberries or other fruit, make a smoothie with bananas and it hides some of the fruit flavors.

I second Brad Ellisor's comment. Our palate are used to processed foods that we no longer enjoy the taste of whole foods. I actually used to be the same way. I ate nothing but fast food and boxed or frozen foods. I hated fruits and vegetables unless it came from a can or was in a flavored Starburst. After learning more about nutrition and cleansing my own palate through cleaning up my diet, I really enjoy fruits and vegetables. I often crave them! Really take a look at what you're consuming to understand why you don't like them. Then work on cleaning up your diet. Lastly, begin introducing them one by one and ensure you try a new fruit or vegetable no less than 4 times before you decide you don't like it. Health starts from within! ~Sunny www.completehealthsb.comwww.facebook.com/SunnyBrigham

Pretty much just force yourself to eat the most "gross" things you can find for a while.  After a couple months, you'll probably start to love the things you found revolting. In An Idiot Abroad, one of my favourite TV shows, Karl Pilkington is eating in China with his friend Warwick Davis. Karl, who began his trip by packing a suitcase full of Monster Munch Crisps, is intentionally eating something he now enjoys, but Warwick finds gross, in an attempt to sort of freak him out. The fact that he went from this:  To this:  Proves that anyone can learn to love some seemingly gross stuff.  Try it!  It make be delicious.

Chocolate & sugar, eh…. Well, would you rather wait until they tell you your life depends on a diet change or do you want to preempt em? Do it on your own? Because that’s where this is heading to & the longer you keep it up the more irreversible damage you cause, but you wouldn’t let it go to that because you’re not stupid………………………………………..right?

Hmm…Well, there is no certain way to fix this but I can recommend some things. Try new things without hesitation. You might find something else you likeThink about those who aren’t as privileged. This might make you feel guilty for not eating your foodPrepare foods you know you like. This way there’s nothing to be picky aboutThese are just 3 simple things that you could try. They may not work but you should still give them a go. I hope this helped answer your question. Good luck!!

You have a head start because you acknowledge your distaste for fruits and vegetables. You also know the nutritional value of eating them. I would suggest starting with small servings of fresh orchard or garden foods such as found at local farmers markets if possible. The texture and taste is so much better than supermarket varieties. Baby steps to a healthier you! Meanwhile, find good supplements until you master it.

Go to the farmers market each week. Find a vegetable. Preferably one you don’t know or don’t like—and buy it. Take it home and look up ways to cook it online, find a recipe that seems good and cook some of it, yourself. Keep cooking one serving of the vegetable until you’ve found a way that you like it. Repeat.

Be open minded and adventurous. I wouldn't say I grew up a "picky" eater, but there were some foods I would have never thought I would eaten (balut or coagulated blood) or enjoyed (sushi). The thought of raw fish I thought was absolutely disgusting. Now I can't get enough of it. Ethnic foods (Indian, Thai, Filipino, and so on) never sounded appealing until I started eating on a more consistent basis. Also, watch cooking shows and travel shows. Shows such as Bizarre Foods and No Reservations really opened my eyes to new cuisines.

Look up recipes for new things, cook it for yourself and sample it as you’re going along. Being presented with a several unfamiliar things (many times mixed together to where you can’t differentiate between them) in one dish has obvious evolutionary reason to incite a reaction of disgust. So take the time to get familiar with them on your own terms.

Well, basically you have to be a grown-up about it. Try something different. If you eat out, order something that sounds healthy and isn’t what you’d usually order, but isn’t TOO far off, either. “Healthy” is a broad category—for example, I promise you’re not going to become horribly ill if you don’t eat kale. It’s okay for you, it’s not a miracle cure-all.

This is not a smart-ass question.  I am asking this with all sincerity.  Have you ever had a ripe, underline RIPE, freestone peach or a slice of a great watermelon?  Grapes are coming back in season and local cantaloupes are plentiful here.  Local fruit is the best.  WE have hundreds, no thousands of acres of corn grown here.  I have already purchased 3 dozen ears. It’s just great!  If you have a Farmers Market buy strawberries or cantaloupes as it is their season.  By eating it at it’s peak  you will at least have a chance of truly enjoying it.  Go to the market and at least try LOCAL fruit and any one local vegetable.  I’ll bet you will like them.

Go to top-rated restaurants that serve up delicious vegetables and desserts. They usually involve being cooked nicely with oils, butters, salts, and sauces and therefore taste really good! You may actually start to like those foods more and the goal would be to eventually cook and eat them in a similar way at home.

Smoothies and pureed soups are a great gateway for getting more fruit & veg in your diet. You can add all sorts of vegetables to a fruit smoothie and you won’t taste it at all. Greens, cucumbers, avocados, tomatoes, carrots. As for cooked vegetables, a nice, creamy soup can hold all sorts of veg. Or top with cheese or dip into ranch. The vitamins don’t disappear if you don’t eat it steamed and plain on a plate.

Look for recipes that incorporate fruits and vegetables into your favorite dishes. Keep trying a variety and savor their differences,. Go u-picking or spur-of-the-moment shopping and see what is truly fresh and work that into your meal. Have good friends over and be creative together!

Be open to new recipes and different kinds of food than what you’re used to. Start with small amounts of the things that you would rather not eat - you might be surprised to find that you like them after all. Go to restaurants that serve different cuisines with unique flavors. Just trying all of these things is an adventurous journey.

You probably picture a stubborn toddler refusing to eat broccoli. But adults can struggle with it, too. They usually have a very limited set of favorite foods, made a certain way. They don't like to try new foods and might even pass on something familiar if it looks, smells, or tastes different than usual.
Eat with other people. ...Add one new food to your diet each week. ...Eat three bites before you turn up your nose at a food. ...Combine foods you don't like with foods you do enjoy.

Putting pressure on yourself to eat -- or being pressured by someone else -- can make it worse because that makes eating less enjoyable. Keep meals as stress-free and pleasant as possible. Try a new food when you're by yourself or with someone who's supportive and nonjudgmental.

At 70 y/o I remain a picky eater. But if you try new, well prepared dishes, you can broaden you palate to include more things to be picky about! Try different foods from reliable sources. Happy dining.

For picky eaters, a treatment plan is usually exposure therapy and counseling. Avoidant restrictive food intake disorder or ARFID is a real problem for some, and you can find a dietitian who works with ARFID clients by searching eating disorder centers in your area.

Try a fruit or vegetable that you never tasted before, or put some grated carrots and/or zucchini in some pasta sauce. Fresh Market sells freeze dried carrots, green beans and other vegetables that are not bad snacks. Add some spinach to tomato soup or a cheese omelet. There are many ways to work in fruits and vegetables if you really want to do it.

Be hungry.    You want to stop being a picky eater, then try forgoing food all together.  When you begin to feel empty for the third day in a row, you will eat your vegetables (or whatever it is you normally avoid.

Think of it as food. A necessity for survival, not a cause of pleasure. You could try to force it upon yourself, like avoid buying your preferred types of food and having only the less desirable ones.
Start by introducing small amounts of veggies to your diet at dinner..try various ones..experiment with recipes make it fun..you'll eventually find at least one you enjoy..hey ones better then none..

You can change it, just force yourself to try new things. On the other hand, why change it? One thing I noticed was that when I was a picky eater, I didn’t eat that much so I was slim. Later when I become less picky, I ate more foods and that made me gain weight. Now that I am trying to lose weight, I find that becoming a picky eater again has its advantages in weight loss.

try to eat what are contents used in fast food. example : if you want to eat burger, then you try to eat cabbage, onion, tomato ….etc. if you want to eat franc fries, then eat boiled potatoes. its hard,but not impossible to do.

I was just like you. But when I realized how important vegetable and fruits are to my digest system, I can't stop eating them. I don't know how to persuade you into it. But I feel so much better after having a wholesome diet. (Psychologically…)
Go in the army for a year

Hunger is a great motivator, not starvation!!! I get a meal for one and share it with them, that way it will cut down on waste and loss of money… try different restaurant and it's best not to tell them what it is…. Even if they liked it… wait til they've eaten it a few times… then they can have their own meal and you don't have to share…

If your baby drinks fluids, similar to juices, water and drain throughout the day, the person will be full by feast time and in all probability won't eat anything. The most ideal path is to adjust the bolstering time for children by offering 3 suppers and one to three snacks at fairly predictable occasions. A ton of youngsters who eat more nibble sustenances and drink liquids throughout the day decline to acknowledge new nourishments. RESOURCE
keep trying new fruits and veg. Your tastebuds will adjust. Be patient - it will take a little time and then you will be amazed how good veggies taste
Hold your nose and eat what is put in front of you because you might not be able to get or buy food tomorrow.

oh yes, if you have experienced boarding school in the UK back in the 80s and survived the barely edible school food i.e. ultra spongy elasticky toasts ; super gummy tepid porridge ; stiff & cold fried eggs with matte yolks ; infinitely mushy baked beans ; deep brown greasy bacon; paper thin pot roast and sticky Yorkshire pudding ; frozen bland pale green peas; lumpy custard sauce with sweet as hell bread pudding; sandy gluey powdery mock mashed potato; oil-dripping soggy sausages…then even the most picky eater will morph into someone who deeply appreciates anything edible and gives thumbs up to mum’s worst cooking.
I cut sugar and processed foods from my diet and my palate changed almost immediately! Now I enjoy foods I never thought I would!

No. I’m a picky eater and always have been. There is food that looks unappealing to me or smells unappealing to me and I won’t even taste it. There are other foods that I crave, take one little tasting bite and I’m done. And I probably won’t ever try them again. When the kale craze started, I bought some in the produce section. Beautiful color, nice and leafy. Got it home and added a bit to my regular salad. Argh! Ick! My whole salad went down the garbage disposal. So I tried drying it in the oven. Supposed to taste like potato chips. Nope, tasted like I’d imagine a dried up cowpie would taste. Never again.
Personally, by acquiring knowledge and experience about nutrition and health, you automatically become a picky eater, because you have to avoid a lot of unhealthy things, but they are offered.
Go camping and bring almost exclusively fruits and veggies. Eventually you’ll get hungry enough to eat it.
Go to India for a week and see how people have to survive on a little food with very little choices just to survive…and you will be fixed! good luck
stop being picky and learn about your food.
Yes of course. Depends on the age of that person too. Children many times will develop more taste for variety. Adults can be stubborn about it.
I guess that guy 101 is mr. right. How is this any different that you having 100 girls before getting married?
